title: The First Bantu Speakers South of the Rainforest: A Cross-Disciplinary Approach to Human Migration, Language Spread, Climate Change and Early Farming in Late Holocene Central Africa
descriptions:
Abstract:

The proposed project, "The First Bantu Speakers South of the Rainforest," aims to elucidate the enigmatic Bantu Expansion, a pivotal event in African history that shaped the continent's linguistic, cultural, and ecological landscape. Focusing on Late Holocene Central Africa, this cross-disciplinary endeavor will investigate the first Bantu-speaking village communities, their timing, location, and archaeological signature, as well as their interactions with hunter-gatherers. By integrating archaeology, archaeobotany, and historical linguistics, we will reconstruct the subsistence strategies, diet, and habitat of these early villagers. Our lexical reconstruction approach will target subsistence and land use, while additional data from archaeozoology, palaeoenvironmental analysis, and genetics will provide a comprehensive understanding of this critical period. Through phylogenetic modeling, we will explore the complex relationships between human migration, language spread, climate change, and early farming. This interuniversity collaboration will provide a holistic view of the Bantu Expansion, shedding light on the controversy surrounding this event and its political repercussions. By addressing the open questions surrounding this pivotal moment in African history, our project will significantly advance our understanding of the complex dynamics that have shaped the continent's past and present.

Title: The First Bantu Speakers South of the Rainforest: A Cross-Disciplinary Approach to Human Migration, Language Spread, Climate Change, and Early Farming in Late Holocene Central Africa

This project seeks to understand the origins and dispersal of the first Bantu-speaking village communities in Late Holocene Central Africa, a topic of ongoing debate and controversy. By integrating archaeological, archaeobotanical, and historical linguistic approaches, we will investigate the timing, location, and archaeological signature of these early villagers, as well as their interactions with hunter-gatherer populations, subsistence strategies, and habitat preferences. Our research will focus on the Democratic Republic of Congo, Republic of Congo, and Angola, and will incorporate additional data from archaeozoology, palaeoenvironmental studies, and genetics. Using phylogenetic modelling and lexical reconstruction, we will reconstruct the subsistence and land use practices of early Bantu speakers and explore the relationships between human migration, language spread, climate change, and early farming in this critical region. This interuniversity collaboration aims to provide a holistic understanding of these interconnected processes, shedding new light on the complex dynamics of human history in Central Africa.

Title: The First Bantu Speakers South of the Rainforest: A Cross-Disciplinary Approach to Human Migration, Language Spread, Climate Change, and Early Farming in Late Holocene Central Africa

This proposal seeks to investigate the origins and dynamics of the Bantu Expansion, a pivotal event in African history that shaped the continent's linguistic, cultural, and demographic landscape. Focusing on the Late Holocene period in Central Africa, our interdisciplinary project will explore the complex relationships between human migration, language spread, climate change, and early farming. By integrating archaeology, archaeobotany, historical linguistics, and additional datasets (archaeozoological, palaeoenvironmental, and genetic), we aim to reconstruct the timing, location, and archaeological signature of the first Bantu-speaking village communities. Our research will examine the interactions between these early villagers and hunter-gatherers, as well as their subsistence strategies, diet, and habitat. Using lexical reconstruction and phylogenetic modeling, we will reconstruct the linguistic and cultural history of the Bantu family, focusing on subsistence and land use. This project's holistic approach will provide a nuanced understanding of the Bantu Expansion's causes and consequences, shedding light on the intricate dynamics of human migration, language spread, and climate change in Late Holocene Central Africa. The proposed research will have significant implications for our understanding of African history, language diversification, and the interconnectedness of human societies and their environments.
